com.storytron.uber

Class Script

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.storytron.uber.Script
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable

    public final class Script
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable, java.io.Serializable

    This class holds an expression tree plus some hooks to the place where the script fits in the storyworld. The nodes of the expression tree are of type DMTN.

    The tree can be of some fixed types listed in the enum Script.Type.

    • Scripts of type Script.Type.AssumeRoleIf have an associated Verb and Role. The role being from the verb.
    • Scripts of type Script.Type.Emotion also have an associated Verb and Role. The role being from the verb, also.
    • Scripts of type Script.Type.Consequence have an associated Verb.
    • Scripts of type Script.Type.OptionAcceptable and Script.Type.OptionDesirable have an associated Verb, Role and Role.Option. The option being from the role, and the role being from the verb.
    • Scripts of type Script.Type.Desirable and Script.Type.Acceptable have an associated Verb, Role, Role.Option and index to a wordsocket. The wordsocket being from the Role.Option, the Option being from the Role, and the Role being from the Verb.
    • Scripts of type Script.Type.OperatorBody have an associated CustomOperator. The custom operator contains the script as its body.

    The method Object.toString() returns a String representing the associations of this script. Each item is identified with its label. For instance, a script of type Script.Type.Acceptable will return "verbCategoryLabel: verbLabel: roleLabel: optionLabel: wordSocketLabel: Acceptable". At some point this was called the script path. You can also get the path with #getPath() and the path components with #getScriptLocators() which is handy if you don't want to parse a string.

    The Script class also provides a method #isValid(Operator, com.storytron.uber.Script.Node), which is used by VerbEditor to determine which operators are valid to use in a given script node. This method is also used for #sniff()ing.

    The #sniff() method tells if all the nodes in a script have valid operators. This is used when pasting scripts and also when loading a storyworld.

    There is a method traverse(com.storytron.uber.Script.NodeTraverser) which executes the method Script.NodeTraverser.traversing(Script, com.storytron.uber.Script.Node) for node in the script. This method is very useful to implement searches or replacements of nodes. As it helps avoiding the hassle of implementing the explicit recursion. There is a similar method Deikto.traverseScripts(com.storytron.uber.Script.NodeTraverser) which is even more powerful as it traverses all the nodes of every script in a storyworld.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Script

        public Script(Script.Type t,
              int tiWordSocket,
              CustomOperator op,
              Operator tOperator,
              boolean tfFillArgs)
        Creates a script instance.

        The arguments describe the script location inside a storyworld. They can be set to null if they are irrelevant for the script location. For instance, an emotional reaction script does not need an option to be located, so the tOption argument my be null.

        Parameters:
        tfFillArgs - tells if default children must be added to the root node.

      • getBaseColor

      • traverse

        public void traverse(Script.NodeTraverser t)

        Traverses the script nodes using the traverser t. Use it like this: 

                s.traverse(new Script.Traverser(){
                public boolean traversing(Script s, DMTN n) {
          do something with s and n
          return true;
        }
        });
        Here "do something with s and n" will be executed for each node in the script s visited in preorder (see Script.NodeTraverser).

      • clone

        public Script clone()
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object

      • toHtml

        public java.lang.String toHtml()
        Recursive routine to convert a script to nice html. Very inefficient, but is used sparingly and scripts are small.

      • deleteNode

        public Script.Node deleteNode(Deikto dk,
                              Script.Node n)
        Deletes a node from the script.
        Returns:
        the new undefined node placed in the script.
